void libariaCapitalize ( libaria_t  str  ) 

Capitalize the string.

This function makes the first character after a sequence of white space upper case

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance

int libariaCharAt ( libaria_t  str,
unsigned long int  i 
)

Get the i-th character.

This function returns the character at the position i of the stored string
The first position is 0

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance
i the index
Returns:
the i-th character or EOF if limits are exceeded

libaria_t  str1,
libaria_t  str2 
)

String concatenation.

This function concatenates str1 with str2 and puts the result in str
The buffer size of str will be increased if necessary

Parameters:
dst libaria_t instance which will hold the result of the concatenation
str1 libaria_t instance
str2 libaria_t instance
Returns:
the length of str or 0 if the buffer could not be increased

libaria_t  str2 
)

String concatenation (in place).

This function concatenates str1 with str2 and keeps the result in str1
The buffer size of str1 will be increased if necessary

Parameters:

str2 libaria_t instance
Returns:
the new length of str1 or 0 if the buffer could not be increased

)

String concatenation (in place).

Returns:

unsigned long int libariaConcatMany ( libaria_t  str,
  ... 
)

Concatenate lots of strings.

This function concatenates all the strings given as argument and places the result in the first argument, str. The strings which are to be concatenated have to be of type char*
The last argument must be NULL

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance which will hold the result
... lots of char* to be concatenated. The last one must be NULL!!
Returns:
the new length of str or 0 if the buffer could not be increased

libaria_t  str2 
)

String copy.

This function places a copy of str2 in str1. The buffer size of str1 will be increased if necessary.

const char* libariaGetChar ( libaria_t  str  ) 

Get a pointer to the string.

This function just calls the LIBARIA_STR() macro, which gives the pointer to the string It returns a const char * because you should only alter the string using the libaria functions

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance
Returns:
a pointer to the string

Create a libaria_t instance.

Returns:
libaria_t instance

libaria_t libariaInit2 ( unsigned long int  n  ) 

Create a libaria_t instance defining the buffer size.

Create a libaria_t instance defining an initial maximum string length This is only the initial maximum. This value will be reajusted when needed

Parameters:
n minimum string size (will be rounded to the next power of 2)
Returns:
libaria_t instance

libaria_t libariaInitChar ( char *  s  ) 

Create and initialize a libaria_t instance.

Create a libaria_t instance and initialize it with a C string (char *) The buffer size will be powerup(strlen(s))

Parameters:

int libariaIsClone ( libaria_t  str1,
libaria_t  str2 
)

libaria instance comparison

This function compares two libaria instances
It returns true if both objects are exactly the same: equal strings and equal buffer size

Parameters:

Returns:

Get string length.

the length of the string (number of characters, without \0)

Remove extra space.

This function replaces sequences of white space with a single space. For example, "a b c d" is transformed into "a b c d"

s2 the substring which will replace s1
Returns:

void libariaResize ( libaria_t  str  ) 

Re-calculate minimum buffer size.

This function re-calculates the minimum buffer size that is needed to keep the current string. If it is less than the currently allocated, the extra memory will be freed
This is the only way to make the buffer smaller. All the other functions will only increase its size when needed

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance to be resized

void libariaReverse ( libaria_t  str  ) 

String reverse.

This function reverses the string stored in str. For example, "abc" is changed to "cba".

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance

unsigned long int  i 
)

i the size of the substring
Returns:
0 or 1 if if fails ou succeeds, respectively

unsigned long int libariaSearch ( libaria_t  str,
char *  s 
)

Search for a substring.

This function searches for the first occurence of s in the string stored at str
Currently uses the KMP algorithm

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance
s the substring to find
Returns:
the index of str where the match occured or LIBARIA_LEN(str) if s was not found

unsigned long int libariaSize ( libaria_t  str  ) 

Get buffer size.

This function just calls the LIBARIA_SIZE() macro, which gives the ammount of currently allocated memory. In other words, it returns the length of the biggest string that is possible to store in str

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance
Returns:
the size of the currently allocated string buffer

Switch upper with lower case and vice-versa.

int libariaUpdate ( libaria_t  str,
const char *  s 
)

Store a new string in a libaria instance.

This function stores the string s in the libaria instance
The buffer will not be resized. If needed, it will be increased, but to make smaller (thus freeing some memory) you must call libariaResize()

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance to store a new string
s char array to be stored in str
Returns:
0 or 1 if it fails or succeeds, respectively

int libariaUpdateFormat ( libaria_t  str,
char *  fmt,
  ... 
)

Store a new string in a libaria instance according to a format.

This function stores a new string in the libaria instance according to a format. The format specifiers are the following:
%s - a C null terminated string
%d - a C int
%A - a libaria_t instance

An example: suppose you want to create the string "select * from t where u='x' and p='y'". Both values x and y are strings. You have one as a libaria_t instance, a1, and the other as a C null terminated string, s1. The following code will do it:

libariaUpdate(str1, "select * from t where u='%A' and p='%s'", a1, s1);

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance to store a new string
fmt the format string
... the remainder arguments, in the same order as they appear in fmt
Returns:
0 or 1 if it fails or succeeds, respectively

void libariaUpper ( libaria_t  str  ) 

Make the string uppercase.

Parameters:
str libaria_t instance

unsigned long int powerup ( unsigned long int  n  ) 

Get the next power of 2.

This function computes the smallest k, such that k is a power of 2 and k > n
If n is already a power of two, it returns 2*n

Parameters:
n integer (not a power of two)
Returns:
smallest power of 2 greater than n
